Loudspeakers, also commonly referred to as speakers, are devices that convert electrical audio signals into corresponding sound waves. They are widely used in various applications such as music systems, public address systems, televisions, computers and mobile phones.

Loudspeakers work on the principle of electromagnetic induction and mechanical displacement. Below is an overview of how they function:

1. Electrical audio signal: An audio source (such as a device playing music) sends an electrical audio signal to the loudspeaker.

2. Amplification: This incoming electrical signal is usually weak so it will typically be sent through an amplifier first to increase its power before reaching the loudspeaker.

3. Driving force: Once amplified, the electrical signal reaches the voice coil present inside the loudspeaker's driver mechanism (which consists of components such as a diaphragm/cone, magnet structure and suspension).

4. Electromagnetic induction: The varying current flowing through this voice coil creates a changing magnetic field around it by inducing electromotive forces between itself and an adjacent stationary permanent magnet which creates attraction or repulsion depending on polarity alignments between them at any given time.
